name: EC2 Instance Storage and Amazon EBS
description: Understanding the differences, use cases, and benefits of EC2 Instance Store and Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS)

cards.front: You are running a temporary caching service on EC2 that doesn’t need to persist after instance termination. What AWS storage type is most appropriate?
cards.back: Amazon EC2 Instance Store is ideal for temporary data like caches and buffers. It provides block-level storage that is deleted when the instance is terminated.
cards.example: A Hadoop cluster uses instance store for fast temporary data replication between nodes.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Instance Storage and Amazon Elastic Block Store

cards.front: You want to ensure data on an EC2 instance persists even if the instance is stopped or terminated. What storage type should you use?
cards.back: Use Amazon EBS, which provides persistent block storage that can be detached from one EC2 instance and attached to another.
cards.example: A production EC2 instance stores database files on EBS to ensure persistence after restarts.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Instance Storage and Amazon Elastic Block Store

cards.front: Which Amazon EBS volume type is best for latency-sensitive, high-transaction workloads like databases?
cards.back: EBS Provisioned IOPS SSD is optimized for I/O-intensive workloads requiring low latency and high throughput.
cards.example: A NoSQL database requires consistent performance, so it’s backed by a Provisioned IOPS SSD volume.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Instance Storage and Amazon Elastic Block Store

cards.front: You need to back up your EC2 data regularly and only want to store changed data to save space. What AWS feature should you use?
cards.back: Use EBS Snapshots. They are incremental backups that only store changes since the last snapshot and are stored redundantly in Amazon S3.
cards.example: An admin takes daily snapshots of a 100 GB volume; after a small update, only 2 GB is stored in the new snapshot.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Instance Storage and Amazon Elastic Block Store

cards.front: Which feature allows you to attach a single EBS volume to multiple EC2 instances simultaneously?
cards.back: EBS Multi-Attach allows a volume to be attached to multiple EC2 instances in the same Availability Zone, though not all instance types support it.
cards.example: Two EC2 instances in the same AZ share access to a multi-attach EBS volume for clustered file system use.
cards.subject: Amazon EC2 Instance Storage and Amazon Elastic Block Store
